Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Nicholas Cornell of University of Texas at Dallas to conduct a research project, entitled "Investigating superconductors with coexisting ferromagnetism," during the summer of 2012 at Zhejiang University in Hangzhou. The host scientist is Huiqiu Yuan.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to better understand the interactions of coexisting phases in a class of iron based superconductors called pnictides. This includes synthesizing new materials of different compositions, measuring them, and making adjustments with the goal of improving their critical temperature and allowing them to withstand stronger magnetic fields while remaining superconducting. Increased magnetic field tolerance would increase their industrial applications and allow them to operate in more environments.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project included synthesis and characterization of iron containing superconductors known as pnictides and their incorporation into composites with carbon nanotubes.  Solid state reaction methods were used to grow both single and polycrystalline samples of Ba(FeCo)2As2, each taking up to a week to grow. Polycrystalline samples additionally had to be reground and pressed into pellets a second time for increased uniformity. All samples of pnictides showed clear superconducting transitions at low temperature with sharp resistance drops.  Samples were made incorporating powders of the superconducting pnictide that were ground in an agate mortar into drawn sheets of carbon nanotubes.  The nanotube sheets were then spun into yarns containing the pnictides by hand.  Variations in amount of pnictide, as well as number of carbon nanotube layers were tested. While the measured results did not show any drop in resistance or obvious superconducting behavior, it is far from exhaustive.  Further research is needed including variations of heat treatment after spinning into yarns.  Additional samples were prepared using carbon nanotubes as a guest into pellets of the pnictide, however, analysis of the composite could not be measured at the time as the structure was unsuitable for transport.  Research continues as well as further collaboration.


Last Modified: 11/30/2012
Modified by: Nicholas L Cornell

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project included synthesis and characterization of iron containing superconductors known as pnictides and their incorporation into composites with carbon nanotubes. Solid state reaction methods were used to grow both single and polycrystalline samples of Ba(FeCo)2As2, each taking up to a week to grow. Polycrystalline samples additionally had to be reground and pressed into pellets a second time for increased uniformity. All samples of pnictides showed clear superconducting transitions at low temperature with sharp resistance drops. Samples were made incorporating powders of the superconducting pnictide that were ground in an agate mortar into drawn sheets of carbon nanotubes. The nanotube sheets were then spun into yarns containing the pnictides by hand. Variations in amount of pnictide, as well as number of carbon nanotube layers were tested. While the measured results did not show any drop in resistance or obvious superconducting behavior, it is far from exhaustive. Further research is needed including variations of heat treatment after spinning into yarns. Additional samples were prepared using carbon nanotubes as a guest into pellets of the pnictide, however, analysis of the composite could not be measured at the time as the structure was unsuitable for transport. Research continues as well as further collaboration. Last Modified: 11/30/2012 Submitted by: Nicholas L Cornell
